--- In gladiator@y..., <Zardus@n...> wrote:

> Visual Basic isn't the most cross-platform thing in existance, but 
if it works, it works. We can always rewrite it in C later for use 
across platforms. It looks good, though. The outside isn't really 
important, its the inside that matters.

I know.  I'm not that familiar with putting together a GUI in C.
 
> Terrain generation can also be incorporated into that later, but I 
think most of us preffer coding in C than in VB. We'll get to that 
later, though.

np.

> That works. Speaking of grids, I wrote a pixedit program yesterday. 
It doesn't actually edit pixes yet, but it views them. Its pixedit.c 
in the utils/ folder if you want to check it out. Latest in CVS works 
quite well.  This will also work for map grid files.

Hmm.  I am going to check that out.  I'm going to have read the specs 
for how the grid file is put together to determine range for 
locations.

> I think the best thing would be to have an option for the amount of 
enemy teams, then distribute foes randomly between them.

Hmm, I'll listen for more opinions.  I'm pretty inclined to let the 
user choose the amount of characters on each team.
 
> If start-up positions arn't specified, the game will scatter your 
team all over the map randomly. If exits arn't specified, the only way 
to get out of the level is to abort.

I'll probably put a generic exit going back to level 1, as a 
placeholder, until I work on a better solution (adjusting my gui to 
allow the user to choose exits)

> Those are all reasonable assumptions and are easy to change in code.

I would like one BIG request for the next version: Do something about 
how the text for each story is displayed.

> Cool. Do you want me to create a subproject for it on Sourceforge so 
that it'll be easily accessable from the sourceforge project page? 
That would also take care of hosting and all that stuff.

Well, I planned on sending you a zip file containing all my work once 
I am finished so others can improve on it.
